div.head: Newes to the Reader, or to whom the Buyer de≈øires to ≈øend Newes.
div.p: SVch is the time, that when friends congratulate, the ≈øecond word is what's the newes? So likewi≈øe, when our vrgent occa≈øions require conference by letters, yet wee expect with tho≈øe letters, what Newes; if we come from the Court, what Newes; if we come from the Countrie, what newes: So from whence≈øoeuer wee come or goe, what Newes. Therefore for them that de≈øire newes, e≈øpecially to you, I pre≈øent the≈øe Netherland accurrents, lately come to my handes from a worthy friend out of Holland, this 18. of Iune. 1607.

div.head: Articles of Agreement concerning the Ce≈ø≈øation of warre, betweene the Arch-duke and the States of the vnited Prouinces.
div.p:
YOu haue heard howe a Fryar, the Confe≈ø≈øor to the Infanta, hath brought about a Ce≈ø≈øation of Armes for 8. moneths, to the end that in that 8. moneths, the≈øe States might acquaint their be≈øt friendes, and coun≈øell them≈øelues, whether they will make a peace or no, vpon rea≈øonable termes; in which it is propounded beforehand, that the Arch-duke ≈øhall di≈øclaime from all intere≈øt in them, and pretence
ouer the≈øe Prouinces vnited, that they ≈øhall, as a free State, treate, and hold all that they now doe, except by con≈øent, ≈øome towne or place may be changed, for the accommodating of the Arch-duke or this States and that the King of Spaine ≈øhall, within the terme of three moneths, ≈øend to the States his agreement to and of the ≈øame Acte.

Now vpon this, there hath beene que≈øtion mooued; fir≈øt concerning the word Inua≈øion, then for the calling home of the Fleet: and what hath beene done in that, I ≈øend you herewith; and the pre≈øent ≈øtate of things here.

Touching the interpretation of that word, it is this concluded; that during the Ce≈ø≈øation, their Prouinces, Territories, and other particular po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions on eyther ≈øide, as well by water as land, ≈øhal be free from all inua≈øion, and all manner of ho≈øtilitie, by Armie, troope, or partie.

That in the neutrall Countries adioyning, no actions of ho≈øtilitie ≈øhall be v≈øed again≈øt the inhabitants pa≈ø≈øengers, & others being no ≈øouldiers, nor again≈øt hor≈øes, driuers of hor≈øes, or tho≈øe men which ≈øhal draw
≈øhippes and boates, on both ≈øides the riuers.

That all actions to the contrary, ≈øhall of all ≈øides bee hindered, puni≈øhed and repaired: with this proui≈øo, that it mu≈øt be vnder≈øtood, that ≈øuch offences committed again≈øt the Contract, tend not to the violation or breaking of the Ce≈ø≈øation vnle≈ø≈øe they bee done by the order and appointment of the King of Spaine or the Arch-duke on the one ≈øide, or the States on the other.

That all ≈øouldiers by land and water, hor≈øe and foot (out of the townes or fortes where they ≈øerue) as al≈øo all others, hauing no pa≈øport or re≈øiding vnder ≈øafegard, all vnfree goods, and the per≈øons and goods which ≈øhall be tran≈øported from one ≈øide to the other, without pa≈øport and licence, are excepted out of tho≈øe limits, and remaine ≈øubiect to the order and rigour of the warre.

That the Contribution on eyther ≈øide (during the Ce≈ø≈øation) ≈øhalbe rai≈øed & executed, as they were at the day of the conclu≈øion of Ce≈ø≈øation, (namely the 12. of Aprill la≈øt) without enhauncement, and at the perill of tho≈øe that ≈øhall execute the ≈øame.

div.head: Touching Ce≈ø≈øation of Armes at Sea.
div.p: THe States haue agreed to call home their Fleete from the coa≈øt of Spaine, with their fir≈øt meanes after the King of Spaines declaration, agreeable to that of his Highne≈ø≈øes, which ≈øhall (according to promi≈øe) be deliuered vnto them; and during the time limitted for the ≈øaid deliuerie, (whereof there is yet ≈øeuen weeks or thereabouts to come) not to re'nforce their ≈øayd Fleete.

That when 6. weekes are expired, after the ≈øaid deliuerie, all prizes (except ≈øhips of warre and ≈øouldiers) which ≈øhall be taken on the ≈øea, from the Gorlings ≈øouth and towards the we≈øt, along the coa≈øt of France, Spaine and Barbary, and in the Straight of Giberalter, and in the Midland ≈øea, ≈øhall be held for vnlawful Prize, and re≈øtorde.

That all Prizes on either part (except ≈øhippes of warre and ≈øouldiers) which ≈øhall bee taken on the north ≈øeas, or on the narrow ≈øeas, betweene great Brittaine and France, as farre as the Gorlings, after the fourteenth of Iune (after their computation)
≈øhall be held for vnlawfull prize, and re≈øtorde.
And tho≈øe Articles of Ce≈ø≈øation to be of force during that limit.

Prouided, that the order pre≈øently ob≈øerued by the States, again≈øt the going out and into the hauens of Flaunders, ≈øhall remaine lawfull for the States to execute, notwith≈øtanding the Ce≈ø≈øation; granted onely to the Arch-duke, that they ≈øhall ≈øuffer his ≈ømall Fi≈øherie without the hauens, during the Ce≈ø≈øation.
I Mu≈øt giue you likewi≈øe the Report of a Fight at Sea, betweene the ≈øhipping of Spaine and the States.

On the 15. of Aprill, 1607. the States Fleete being 29. ≈øhippes of warre, and proui≈øion, arriued in the Bay of Giberalter, where they found the Armado of Spaine, about 12. or 13. ≈øhips of warre, (be≈øides ≈øeuen or eight Marchants) who had order to hale on the Hollanders, going in or out

The Admirall with another good ≈øhippe, commanded by Captaine Lambrecht, boarded the Spani≈øh Admirall with full ≈øayle, and beat her ≈øo violently with ordinance and musket, that in a ≈øhort ≈øpace ≈øhe lo≈øt her Generall, with almo≈øt 300. men, being a ≈øhip of 400. la≈øt or burthen, manned with 500. and carrying 21. great bra≈ø≈øe peeces.

After fiue houres fight, the States had the victorie, but with danger: for fire happening in the Spani≈øh Viceadmirall, when ≈øhe was grappled, the States ≈øhippes had much adoe to ≈øaue them≈øelues from burning. The Spani≈øh Admirall with ≈øome others ran aground, ≈øuffred the fire to lay hold on them, and increa≈øed it, to preuent the States profit by taking them. The next day examining the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, they left (of the 21. ≈øhippes which they found in the Bay at their ariual) but two Gallions, one French ≈øhip, and a ≈ømall pinna≈ø≈øe all which were ≈øo grounded, that they could neither take nor burne them.

Three Marchants be≈øides, comprehended in the 21. committed them≈øelues to the States fleete. So that the Spaniard lo≈øt ≈øeuen great Gallions, and ≈øixe or ≈øeuen other good ≈øhippes be≈øides. The States lo≈øt their Admirall with the fir≈øt ≈øhot from the Spani≈øh Admirall; and among others, one captaine Laughen Heyndricke of Am≈øterdam, and captaine Lambrechts ≈øonne.
They haue great hurt done to their ma≈øts, ≈øayles, cables, and tacklins.

I Mu≈øt further let you know, that certaine ≈øhippes of the≈øe Countries, of the Company that trades to the Ea≈øt Indies, haue taken a very rich Carracke, which they haue lightned of her mo≈øt precious and rich lading, and laden it into their owne ≈øhips, of which, one is come into Am≈øterdam, and the other into Zeland, and the Carracke, into which they haue put their Spices, is comming al≈øo.
THe French Amba≈ø≈øadours are gone a progre≈ø≈øe into North Holland, attending the enlarging of their Commi≈ø≈øion.
THe mo≈øt of the≈øe people conceiue and feare, that the king of Spaine wil neuer ≈øend the Agreeation, vpon which mo≈øt depends. Iune 16. 1607. From the Haghe.

div.head: Later Newes.
div.p: THere are letters come from Bred√§, that 2000 Spaniards are entred a backe way into the Ca≈øtle of Antwerpe, haue turned the Artillerie vpon the Towne, and doe make warre with the Citizens. This is beleeued at the Haghe: but I will not report it for trueth, vntil the fir≈øt be ≈øeconded. Farewel. From the Haghe, Iune 16. 1607.

lg.l: THe ≈øickne≈ø≈øe great that doth oppre≈ø≈øe my hart,
And cau≈øe each veine & pul≈øe to pant & beat,
As ≈øignes that ≈øoule and body mu≈øt depart,
Do ≈øhew, that ≈øpight my heart, I cannot let
The houre ta'pproch which fatal death hath ≈øign'd;
For all things mu≈øt returne vnto their kind.
And ≈øith 'tis ≈øo, I then am fully bent,
Before I part, for to declare my Will,
And make my la≈øt and fatall Te≈øtament,
And to each one, great, little, good, or ill,
Bequeath my goods, and all that I po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe,
And teach all the≈øe that Martiall Art profe≈ø≈øe,
How to deui≈øe the Warres for to increa≈øe,
And make them wor≈øe and greater then before,
And find the meanes that they ≈øhall neuer cea≈øe,
And that each countrie people, rich and poore,
May feele the edge of my deuouring blade,
Which in the world ≈øuch ≈ølaughter great hath made.
For though I die, and Netherlands for≈øake,
Yet mu≈øt you thinke, that I mine heires do leaue,
That will not fayle in ought my part to take,
And Countries farre and neere of peace bereaue,
And make my fame, when I am dead and rotten,
Still to increa≈øe, and neuer be forgotten.
Fir≈øt I bequeath vnto the Potentate,
That many men hath brought vnto their end,
By my contentious bloudy mind and hate,
Great ≈øtore of goods and lands, his ≈øtate to mend,
And though he ≈øerued me with great de≈øire,
And rather ≈øought for wealth, then warre require,
And happily full many dangers pa≈øt:
Yet let him know, what euer he hath woon,
That from it all he mu≈øt depart at la≈øt,
When he his fatall cour≈øe on earth hath runne;
And therefore coun≈øell him for to beware,
And of his life to haue a better care.
To Tyrants great, to whom their law is will,
Who by my means much wrong & hurt haue done
By fal≈øe pretence of warre, and ≈øought to kill
Both man and child, and many Countries woon
By fire and ≈øword, con≈øuming townes and towers,
And wrongfully de≈øtroyed plea≈øant Bowers,
I doe bequeath Kains cur≈øe and bani≈øhment,
And though their fame b'extold vnto the aire,
Yet ≈øhall their hearts and minds be di≈øcontent,
And filled with confu≈øion and de≈øpaire,
And at the la≈øt with woe and mi≈øerie,
Their bodies ≈øhall with lice con≈øumed be.
To tho≈øe that haue bin valiant, ≈øtout and bold,
T'aduenture life and limme for to defend
Their Countries cau≈øe, and it from dangers hold,
And haue continued true vnto the end,
Offered no wrong, nor v≈øed villanie,
But with their pay them≈øelues did ≈øatisfie,
I cannot chu≈øe but wi≈øh them well in heart,
And prai≈øe and honor leaue them for their meed,
And when that they out of this world ≈øhall part,
De≈øire of God to helpe them in their need,
And giue them con≈øtant faith for to per≈øeuer,
In godly life to liue with him for euer.
To Spirituall men, that are of carefull mind,
To preach and teach, I cannot leaue them much,
And they do know, and well by proofe do find,
Their Cloi≈øters ≈øpoild, whereat they ≈øeeme to grutch,
Their Churches burnt, their liuing ta'ne away,
And which is more, where they haue ≈øeen the day,
That all their Sellers ≈øtored were with drinke,
Their Barnes full, their Kitchins fraught with meat,
And all things els what euer heart could thinke,
Were in their Hou≈øes found, now nought to get,
And they poore Prie≈øts & Couents without land,
To other mens reuer≈øions forc't to ≈øtand.
Vnto the Townes in Netherlands ≈øo great,
I do bequeath and leaue a great Exci≈øe,
And many Impo≈øitions that are ≈øet
Vpon them, though they rather would deui≈øe
The meanes to liue in peace and quiet ≈øtate,
And thinke them≈øelues to be mo≈øt fortunate.
Meane time they mu≈øt behold their ra≈øed walles,
Their Towers ca≈øt downe, vncouered and defac't,
Their Hou≈øes burnt, their Palaces and Halles
Euen with the ground: for what can euer la≈øt,
But mu≈øt of force con≈øume and eke decay?

Vnto the countrie Village and the Towne,
I do bequeath a de≈øolate e≈øtate,
And vncoth ≈øight of Ca≈øtlis, broken downe,
And hou≈øes ≈øpoylde, which warre vnfortunate
Hath cau≈øde and made full many a man to bee
Amazed lore ≈øuch wofull ≈øights to ≈øee:
I leaue them Sluces fallne vnto decay,
Great ≈øtore of lame and mi≈øerable folke,
Murthers committed 'mong≈øt them night and day,
Women deflowrde, and men brought vnder yoke

To tho≈øe that by di≈ø≈øention and by ≈øtrife,
Deceit and ≈øubtiltie haue gotten wealth,

Haue liu'd by cou≈øinage, and by ≈øecret ≈øtealth,

And V≈øurers, and ≈øuch as liue by gaine,

To ≈øcape ≈øo well, and as the world well knowes,

To Armorers and Spurriers by their Art,

Your Hor≈øemens boyes, Dead paies, & Billet men,
